Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Engineering a Low-Cost Polymer Composite Based on Recycled Carbon Fibers

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Carbon fiber reinforced polymer composites have high strength-to-weight ratios and are corrosion free which make them attractive to the aerospace and automotive industries. Recycling carbon fiber composites from end-of-life products leads to resource and energy savings, with a variety of benefits including a reduction in the need for landfills currently used for end-of-life composite products. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project capitalizes on a novel technology to recycle carbon fiber composites where the polymer matrix, including all its toxic byproducts, are removed, and minimal damage, if any, occurs to the carbon fibers. A new class of polymer composites based on recycled carbon fibers will be investigated. This novel composite is estimated to cost only 20 percent of the cost of virgin carbon fiber composites and is expected to achieve an acceptable combination of mechanical properties. The research will be conducted at University of New Mexico, which is a Minority and Hispanic-Serving Institution (MHSI), will include a local industrial partner, Adherent Technologies Inc., and will also engage students at the Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute (SIPI) who will be participate in the composite recycling, fabrication, and testing.

This research aims at investigating the fundamental processes required to develop a new class of low-cost carbon fiber reinforced composites, from recycled carbon fibers, with appreciable strength and ductility, yet with a stiffness suitable for a wide range of applications. Understanding the processing-structure-mechanical property relationships in these novel recycled composites is key to realizing their potential. This research will investigate the role of fiber-fiber interactions, fiber length and morphology, fiber volume fraction, fiber surface quality and reactivity, and sizing-matrix compatibility on the mechanical behavior of this new composite. The recycled carbon fibers can produce a new class of composites containing long, entangled fibers and are therefore different from both conventional continuous and chopped fiber composites. This unique feature provides an opportunity to engineer the composite by manipulating fiber orientation and length as well as altering the fiber-matrix interfaces to achieve a combination of mechanical properties not possible using current fibers.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims at examining the potential of using recycled carbon fibers to produce new class of composites for structural applications. Recycled carbon fiber composites have the potential to bring a transformational change in many industries by providing an inexpensive and environmentally friendly composites with high mechanical performance. The recycled carbon fibers offer significant material savings, estimated to save 80-90% of the energy used in the production of virgin carbon fibers, thus providing a very significant CO2 emission reduction. Moreover, remanufacturing high performance composites form recycled carbon fibers offers an ultimate solution to the pressing issue of closing the lifecycle of CFRP.

In this research, we examined the effect of recycling process and sizing on surface chemistry and strength of fiber and fiber/matrix interface. Our analysis showed that single fibers retained 100% of stiffness and up to 90% of strength of the virgin fibers.  Sizing the fibers with a sizing polymer was an essential step to improve fiber bond to the matrix. Sizing resulted in surface groups leading into high interfacial strength and thus improved mechanical properties of the composites. Effect of fiber alignment on mechanical properties was also elucidated. It is apparent that aligning the fibers can result in producing recycled fiber composites with much improved mechanical properties including strength and strain compared with unaligned fibers. Our investigations also showed water processing of the fibers might have a negative effect on the recycled fiber composite. It is apparent that unsized fibers are prone to water absorption and there is a high possibility of entrapping water molecules that would prevent developing good bond with the fibers. It is also concluded that nanomaterials would have little impact on the recycled fiber composites unless a relatively high fiber volume fraction ~30% is achieved. It was also determined that shear alignment (through stretching) of fibers in a thermoplastic or viscous thermoset can achieve a high level of alignment. Finally, without significant efforts on alignment, it is possible to produce recycled fiber composites with fiber volume fraction as high as ~ 25% with strengths that represent 50-90% that of plain weave glass fibers used for infrastructure applications.

Finally, three students: 1 PhD, 1 MSc and 1 undergraduate student were trained on the different aspect of the project and gained skills in writing, scientific design of experiments, and communication and presentation skills. Furthermore, a two-day workshop including the PIs and the three above students and at least 20 Native American Students in Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute (SIPI) was developed and included training SIPI students on advanced composites and composite recycling technology.

 


Last Modified: 04/02/2017
Modified by: Mahmoud Reda Taha

Recycled carbon fiber composites have the potential to bring a transformational change in many industries by providing an inexpensive and environmentally friendly composites with high mechanical performance. The recycled carbon fibers offer significant material savings, estimated to save 80-90% of the energy used in the production of virgin carbon fibers, thus providing a very significant CO2 emission reduction. Our analysis showed that single fibers retained 100% of stiffness and up to 90% of strength of the virgin fibers. Sizing the fibers with a sizing polymer was an essential step to improve fiber bond to the matrix. Finally, three students: 1 PhD, 1 MSc and 1 undergraduate student were trained on the different aspect of the project and gained skills in writing, scientific design of experiments, and communication and presentation skills.
